data.title: Jonah crab and egg yolk bottarga

items.description: For Spring and Summer and we started getting in Jonah crab. So we whip up just enough cream cheese and yogurt to bind the ingredients together and give the dish sweet and sour elements, then add lime juice to lighten the dish.

morsel.title: Jonah crab and egg yolk bottarga

items.description: Gremolata is one of those dishes where everyone has their own interpretation of how it should be made. Basically it's a chopped condiment and for ours, we focus on lime zest and parsley. Then we add cubed potatoes to give the salad some body.

morsel.title: Jonah crab and egg yolk bottarga

items.description: The garnish is shaved preserved egg yolk. It's basically bottarga but we make it inhouse with chicken egg. We cure it in salt and sugar for 14 days. It gives the dish a nice saltiness.

morsel.title: Jonah crab and egg yolk bottarga

items.description: The idea of egg yolk and crab is delicious. And it also gives the dish a beautiful color.

morsel.title: Jonah crab and egg yolk bottarga

items.description: Crab salad with cured egg yolk and lime.

morsel.title: Jonah crab and egg yolk bottarga

items.description: Sardines are an absolute favorite of mine & Phil's and the best way to really get the true flavor is to pickle them.

We leave them in the cure for 8-10 hours in salt, sugar, black pepper and coriander to tighten up the flesh Then we rinse them and pickle them for two days in a white vinegar pickle. Then we marinade in the olive oil we've marinated our olives in.

For the record, we then use that same olive oil for cooking our tuna, giving that dish some extra background notes.
It's a classic hummus, with tahini, roasted garlic, olive oil and a bit of cayenne.

What's interesting about cooking at Cicchetti is that my career used to be about searching for the next thing and now, I'm focused on just making food people will like. It's about being delicious first and new/innovative second.
Pickled sardines with fresh hummus crostini.

We get a half cow at least every week at Three Aces. Most of it gets ground up for hamburgers and bolognese, and while most of the bone marrow is made into bone marrow salt, there's always extra bone marrow sitting around. So, I decided to make a cake.

Obviously, a cake made with bone marrow is pretty intense, so the first step in putting this dish together was to push hard against the fat. Cocoa nibs add about as much bitterness to a dessert as one could find.
Texture was the second challenge. A brittle offers up some great texture.
I added coffee to the whipped cream to tone it down a bit. It's still whipped cream, but the coffee adds some balance.
The dish actually began as bacon fat cake, for BaconFest, but I couldn't put that on the menu and give away my idea. Which is why I ended up with bone marrow cake.

On the menu it reads: Chocolate-marrow pound cake, coffee whipped cream, cocoa nib brittle. It's pretty intense. Moist and delicious like a cake is supposed to be. You'd never guess it started with a piece of bone marrow.

This dish was first created for a Jolly Pumpkin beer dinner. They make great beer, but they're sour beers and I am not a big fan of sour beers. Its kinda difficult coming up with the dishes in that situation, but basically my thought was to hit a point and a counterpoint flavor for each beer. Scallops are a good choice because they are a workhorse. as a protein, they can really go with just about everything. It takes one variable out of the equation.

David Odd, the forager, just gave me some rose hips one day and they were pretty much sitting around for a while as I tried to think of what I wanted to do with them. When I was going through the tasting notes for the Beaudelaire IO and they seemed to have a lot of floral notes, like rosehips, so it was an obvious match.

The Jolly Pumpkin Baudelaire IO has notes of rose hips and black pepper. That became the obvious choice for the sauce and along with the arugula were the matching points, the high notes. The counterpoints worked hard against the tartness of the beer (bacon, roasted sunflower seeds, scallop, cornbread), making up the low notes.
I love this sauce because it kinda looks like BBQ sauce but it is tart and light and floral, which is really surprising.

It's always a challenge to come up with delicious food when it's a flavor profile I'm not a huge fan of. I try and remove myself from the equation and figure what is it about these flavors that people enjoy. Then it is just a matter of making a balanced dish.

The dish is simply scallops with black pepper-rose hip sauce, cornbread panzanella and arugula. It's a great pairing with sour beers. The delicate scallops balanced with hearty cornbread and the bite of arugula makes for a dish that can stand up to the complexity of sours.

Remember back to that first brutally cold below 40 day? Well, on that day, my girlfriend and I were sitting in the couch trying to think up the hottest food we could eat. Polenta is some serious bubbling hotness and stays hot even after you eat it. This dish started there and we obviously brought it to the restaurant because it wasn't just cold that one day. It was cold forever.
We do a straight up chicken thigh and root vegetable ragu and add porchetta sausage, which is a signature staple in the Three Aces kitchen

A great egg is a thing of beauty. We actually tried to keep chickens at the restaurant. We built a beautiful coop in our oversized parking lot but the city would have none of it. Those eggs would have been delicious.

Simple flavors. Put together well. Usually that's all it takes to make great food. And when you're battling just getting to work and back home during a Chicago winter, uncomplicated is definitely the way to go.

So, on the menu it reads Chicken Thigh Ragu with Italian Sausage, Root Vegetables, Spoon Polenta, Poached Farm Egg, Parmesan and grilled ciabatta. It's pretty rustic and it will keep you pretty warm when you go out to shovel. Again.

Every country ham starts with a pig. For the country ham we served at the Good Food Festival, we started with this rare Guinea Hog from Spence Farm. Note the rich veins of leaf fat. This would be a well-marbled specimen to make exceptional cured hams.

The hams are cured with trotter on. The cure is a mixture of brown sugar, kosher salt, curing salt (instacure #2) and spices bay, allspice, coriander, cayenne, anise, and clove. It must be carefully rubbed into the skin and all exposed flesh to effectively block any pathways for bacteria to enter the ham. They cure for 1.5 days per pound, 2/3 of which is spent thigh joint-side up, the remainder skin-side up.

Next, the cure is carefully washed off and they are left to dry for a day. Now cured, they are able to rest at ambient temperature and no longer require refrigeration. They are cold-smoked for two days with pecan wood.

According to the historic Appalachian country ham practice, after smoking the hams would remain hanging  in the smokehouse until needed, and for a true country ham this would mean at least 6-8 months. Part of this process involves exposure to the elements, as smokehouses were typically spare buildings of wood or uninsulated brick. They hams sweat in the summer, freeze in the winter, and otherwise generally respirate while ultimately giving up 25% or more of their weight through water loss. This intensifies the cure and prolongs storability as less moisture means less potential for microbial activity. Meanwhile, the flavor intensifies and develops complexity...

After a year or more of curing, we have a handsome specimen. True Appalachian country hams are only now gaining their much-deserved respect as rivaling the great iberico hams of the Spanish Pata Negra. Carved and eaten uncooked as charcuterie, they are in my opinion one of the greatest pork products in the world, and easy to make for anyone with the ambition, means, and patience.

All of our charcuterie begins with a whole hog. Each part of the animal is put to good use, from the head to tail, and even the blood, which is used to make boudin rouge, a Cajun blood sausage bound with rice. It's increasingly hard to find nowadays even in Louisiana. So it's something we've focused on to sustain, document, and revive.

Boudin rouge starts with a very fatty grind - we use a 50/50 lean/fat ration comprised of trim from the hams for lean and trim from the lower belly, or groin, for fat. This grind will make up 40% of the final weight, so it's just the base.
Three add-ins, apple brandy, port wine, and chopped fatback taken from the primal loin add flavor, aroma, and a pretty finished interior in the case of the fatback, which is 29% of the total weight.

One of the most important steps of making blood sausage is emulsifying the forcemeat. Everything has to be very, very cold and is mixed in a stand mixer. First the ground meat is whipped until it resembles sticky mayonnaise, then the blood is added in a thin, steady stream so the emulsion holds while it's being mixed in. Next come the ricesnd fatback.
The finished forcemeat resembles a thick, lumpy milkshake.
Stuffing voiding rouge into hog middle casings is a delicate process, and one 20# batch makes about 25 feet of finished sausage.

It's a messy process, one that takes great care in maintaining a clean work area during production and just as importantly, cleaning up afterwards. Next, the sausages get poached in a steaming saltwater brine at 170 degrees Fahrenheit until they reach an internal temperature of 165.

The finished sausage is chilled under cold running water to stop the cooking and refrigerated before serving. It's a joy to look.at when sliced on a plate, and an even greater joy to let melt on your tongue.
Start with a ham....
Femur & sirloin tip removed
Rub inside and out. This particular marinade: garlic, jalapeo,orange juice & zest, lime juice & zest, cumin & salt. It will sit in this for 48 hours.
Tied and ready for the oven!
The finished plate. Served with spicy cabbage and a potato roll.

The month of September marks the first official day of fall, and even though the cooler months ahead bring a variety of things to be excited about (pumpkin spice lattes?), it can also be a sad time for farm-to-table restaurants, as we bid adieu to some of our favorite summer produce  like tomatoes.

So before its too late  and grocery stores will be stocking up on rock-hard, flavorless objects referred to as \"tomatoes\"  be sure to stop by and order our new Warm Tomato appetizer. JV started the dish by making his own fruit leather, or \"fruit roll-up\" as he likes to call it. While it was a bit of an experiment, he combined tomato peel and apple puree with some sugar, and then cooked down the mixture until it was super thick. After that, he spread it out on a piece of plastic wrap to set  and voil! It worked.

To build the dish, JV sliced and layered a perfectly ripe tomato (that was first warmed on a hot plate), and then followed up with a drizzle of sunflower seed yogurt sauce and a few thinly sliced strips of the fruit leather.
He finished it off with fresh dill, lots of rich olive oil, freshly ground black pepper and a warm baguette for dipping. All of this can be yours for just $13.
